questions.text: The inner ear, or the labyrinth has a central chamber called the vestibule with a spherical and elliptical recess, each accommodating important structures of the membranous labyrinth. What structure does the elliptical recess accommodate?

A 35-year-old patient presents with complaints of vertigo and dizziness when turning their head side to side. Upon examination, the nystagmus is horizontal. Which of the following is the most likely stimulated structure?
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Description

Horizontal/Lateral Semicircular Canal (Option B)

Detects rotations around the vertical axis;

produces horizontal nystagmus.

Superior/Anterior Semicircular Canal (Option A)

Detects anterior-posterior head movements;

produces rotatory nystagmus.

Posterior Semicircular Canal (Option C)

Detects vertical head movements;

produces vertical nystagmus.

Utricle and Saccule (Option D)

Responds to linear acceleration and deceleration or gravitational pull during head tilts.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with vertigo, nausea, and vomiting. His vertigo worsens with sudden head movements, and he shows signs of horizontal nystagmus. Which of the following best describes the central vestibular connections responsible for his symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Vestibular nuclei efferents to the cerebellum provide motion awareness.

options.label: B
options.text: The vestibulo-ocular reflex involves CN III, IV, and VI via the MLF.

options.label: C
options.text: Vestibulospinal fibers connect directly to the cerebellum for balance.

options.label: D
options.text: The autonomic system plays no role in vestibular disorders.

questions.correct_answer: B. The vestibulo-ocular reflex involves CN III, IV, and VI via the MLF.
questions.explanation:
Component

Function

Vestibular Nerve

Formed by central processes of bipolar cells in Scarpa’s ganglion, it transmits signals from the labyrinth to the brain.

Vestibular Nuclei

Four in number (superior, medial, lateral, descending) located in the brainstem; integrate inputs from vestibular receptors, cerebellum, reticular formation, and spinal cord.

Vestibulo-ocular Reflex (VOR)

Mediated by vestibular nuclei sending efferent fibers to cranial nerves III, IV, and VI through the medial longitudinal bundle, stabilizes gaze during head movement.

Vestibulospinal Pathway

Efferent fibers from vestibular nuclei to the motor part of the spinal cord coordinate head, neck, and body movements.

Cerebellar Connections

Receives inputs from vestibular nuclei (vestibulocerebellar fibers) to coordinate balance and maintain body equilibrium.

Autonomic Nervous System

Explains nausea, vomiting, sweating, and pallor seen in vestibular disorders like Ménière’s disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with involuntary oscillatory eye movements, vertigo and hearing loss in the right ear. The nystagmus is horizontal, with a fast phase to the right, more pronounced in darkness and improves when focusing on a fixed point. There is no associated nausea or vomiting. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Central vestibular nystagmus due to a cerebellar lesion

options.label: B
options.text: Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis

options.label: C
options.text: Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to purulent labyrinthitis

options.label: D
options.text: Central vestibular nystagmus due to Arnold-Chiari malformation

questions.correct_answer: B. Peripheral vestibular nystagmus due to serous labyrinthitis
questions.explanation:
Feature

Peripheral Nystagmus

Central Nystagmus

Location of lesion

Labyrinth or vestibulocochlear (VIII) nerve

Central neural pathways (vestibular nuclei, brainstem, cerebellum)

Latency

2-20 seconds

No latency

Duration

Less than 1 minute

More than 1 minute

Type of Nystagmus

Spontaneous nystagmus

Gaze-Evoked Nystagmus

Direction of Nystagmus

Fixed, towards the undermost ear

Change with direction of gaze

Fatigability

Fatigable

Non-fatigable

Response to Visual Fixation

Suppressed by Optic fixation; Worsens in darkness or with Frenzel glasses (+20 dioptre glasses), both abolishing optic fixation

Cannot be suppressed

Accompanying Symptoms
  • Severe vertigo
  • Loss of hearing in one ear
  • Ringing in one or both ears
  • Difficulty focusing vision
  • Loss of balance

None or slight:

  • Impairment in speech
  • Weakness or numbness
  • Gait disturbance
  • Impairment in vision

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the Fitzgerald-Hallpike manoeuvre is false?

options.label: A
options.text: The temperature of the water used for stimulation is 44°C for hot water and 30°C for cold water.

options.label: B
options.text: A gap of 8-10 minutes is maintained between the cold and hot water stimulations to avoid cross-contamination of effects.

options.label: C
options.text: A normal response to cold water stimulation is horizontal nystagmus towards the ipsilateral side.

options.label: D
options.text: The test helps to assess vestibular function and can indicate central pathology if directional preponderance is observed.

questions.correct_answer: C. A normal response to cold water stimulation is horizontal nystagmus towards the ipsilateral side.
questions.explanation:
Purpose

Induces nystagmus by thermal stimulation of the vestibular system; tests each labyrinth separately. Assesses if vertigo induced by the test is similar to the patient's episodes, indicating labyrinthine origin.

Modified Kobrak Test
  • Procedure: Patient seated with head tilted 60° back. Ear irrigated with ice water (5, 10, 20, 40 mL) for 60 s.
  • Normal Response: Nystagmus towards the opposite ear with 5 mL.
  • Hypoactive Labyrinth: Response with increased volumes of water.
  • Dead Labyrinth: No response to 40 mL

Fitzgerald-Hallpike Test (Bithermal Caloric Test)
  • Procedure: Patient supine with head tilted 30° forward. Ears irrigated alternately with water at 30°C and 44°C for 40 s each.
  • Observation: Record time taken from start of irrigation to end of nystagmus; chart on a calorigram.
  • Re-test: With water at 20°C if no nystagmus is seen.
  • Observation: Cold water causes nystagmus to the opposite side and warm water to the same side.
  • Assessment:
    • Canal Paresis: Weaker response from one side compared to the other.
    • Directional Preponderance: Nystagmus is more on one side than the other, 25%-30% or more difference. Occurs towards the side of a central lesion and away from the side of a peripheral lesion.

Cold-Air Caloric Test
  • Procedure: Cold air is blown into the ear via a Dundas Grant tube cooled by ethyl chloride.
  • Use: For cases with tympanic membrane perforation.
  • Type: Rough qualitative test.

questions.text: While assessing a patient’s vestibular function, an ENT surgeon repeatedly presses and releases the tragus of the patient, eliciting a positive response. What would this finding indicate?
questions.explanation:
Purpose

To Assess the integrity of the bony labyrinth and detect perilymph fistulas (abnormal openings in the bony labyrinth)
 

Principle

Pressure changes in the external ear canal can be transmitted to the inner ear through a fistula, triggering vestibulo-ocular reflex (VOR), resulting in nystagmus and possibly vertigo
 

Procedure
  • Pressure Application: Intermittent pressure applied on the tragus or using a Siegel's speculum.
  • Observation: Eyes are observed for nystagmus and the patient is queried about vertigo.
 

Interpretation
  • Positive Fistula Test:
    • Indicates a perilymph fistula
    • Nystagmus direction helps locate the fistula
    • Indicates a functional labyrinth
  • Negative Fistula Test:
    • Usually indicates intact bony labyrinth
    • False negatives can occur if covered by cholesteatoma
 

Positive test causes
  • Erosion of horizontal semicircular canals as in cholesteatoma
  • Surgically created window in horizontal canal
  • Superior canal dehiscence
  • Abnormal opening in the oval or round window

Negative test
  • No fistula

False-negative causes

  • Surgically confirmed cases of labyrinthine fistula
  • Cholesteatoma covers the site of fistula
  • Dead labyrinth
 

False-Positive (Hennebert's Sign)

Hennebert's Sign: Positive test without a fistula; can occur in:

  • Congenital Syphilis: Hypermobile stapes footplate.
  • Ménière's Disease: Due to a distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated in the ENT clinic for vertigo when she gets up from bed. Which of the following tests would be useful for diagnosing benign paroxysmal positional vertigo?
Which of the following statements is false about vestibular evoked myogenic potentials?

options.label: A
options.text: The cervical VEMP is picked up in the sternocleidomastoid

options.label: B
options.text: The vestibulospinal arc mediates through the lower brainstem

options.label: C
options.text: The ocular muscle that show potentials are the inferior oblique and inferior rectus

options.label: D
options.text: It can be used in diagnosing the origin of a neuroma

questions.correct_answer: C. The ocular muscle that show potentials are the inferior oblique and inferior rectus
questions.explanation:
cVEMP (Cervical VEMP)

oVEMP (Ocular VEMP)

Target muscle

Sternocleidomastoid (SCM) muscle in the neck

Ocular muscles (inferior oblique or superior rectus)
 

Nerve pathway

Saccule → Inferior vestibular nerve → Vestibular nuclei → Ipsilateral vestibulospinal tract → Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) → SCM

Utricle → Superior vestibular nerve → Vestibular nuclei → Medial longitudinal fasciculus → Oculomotor nerve (CN III) → Inferior oblique and superior rectus muscles
 

Stimulation

  • Primarily, air-conducted sounds stimulate the saccule
  • Bone-conducted sounds, stimulating both saccule and utricle
 

Clinical uses

  • Assessing saccular function
  • Investigating acoustic neuroma (inferior vestibular nerve)
  • Diagnosing Ménière's disease
  • Assessing utricular function
  • Investigating acoustic neuroma (superior vestibular nerve)
  • Diagnosing superior canal dehiscence
 

Differences

  • Sensitive to air-conducted sounds
  • Vestibulospinal arc is mediated through the lower brain stem
  • Responds to both air and bone conduction
  • Vestibulo-ocular reflex is mediated through the upper brainstem

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with sudden-onset vertigo and difficulty maintaining gaze stability during head movements. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to assess vestibulo-ocular reflex?
questions.explanation:
Clinical Tests

Laboratory Tests
  • Spontaneous nystagmus
  • Fistula test
  • Romberg test
  • Gait
  • Post-Pointing and Falling
  • Dix-Hallpike Maneuver (Positional Test)
  • Tests of cerebellar dysfunction
  • Head thrust test
  • Supine roll test
  • Unterberger test (Fukuda stepping test)
  • Caloric test
  • Electronystagmography
  • Optokinetic test
  • Rotation test
  • Galvanic test
  • Posturography
  • Dynamic visual acuity test
  • Vestibular-evoked myogenic potentials (VEMP)

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman comes to the ENT department complaining of vertigo. She also has double vision, with nystagmus and difficulty in swallowing but no hearing loss . Which of the following disorders could be a cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Peripheral Vestibular Disorders (Option A)

Central Vestibular Disorders
 

Origin

Inner ear or vestibular nerve (cranial nerve VIII)

Brainstem, cerebellum, or other central nervous system structures




 

Examples
  • Ménière's Disease
  • Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
  • Vestibular Neuronitis
  • Labyrinthitis
  • Vestibulotoxic Drugs
  • Head Trauma
  • Perilymph Fistula
  • Acoustic Neuroma
  • Syphilis
  • Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
  • Posteroinferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) Syndrome(Wallenberg syndrome)
  • Basilar Migraine
  • Cerebellar Disease
  • Multiple Sclerosis
  • Tumors of the Brainstem and Cerebellum
  • Epilepsy
  • Cervical vertigo

Symptoms

Vertigo, often with hearing loss, tinnitus, and aural fullness

Vertigo, often with additional neurological symptoms like double vision, difficulty swallowing, drop attacks, or weakness
 

Hearing Loss

Common, especially with inner ear disorders (e.g., Ménière's disease, labyrinthitis)

Less common, central disorders typically do not affect hearing directly
 

Nystagmus Characteristics

Often changes direction based on gaze; typically intermittent

May be direction-fixed or more persistent; often associated with other neurological signs
 

Compensation

Often improves over time as the brain adapts; recovery can be expected

Less predictable; central disorders may not fully compensate, leading to chronic symptoms

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of severe vertigo, fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, tinnitus, and a sensation of fullness in the left ear. An Audiogram is taken and is shown below. Which of the following structures is primarily involved in the pathophysiology of the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Structure

Role in Ménière's Disease

Endolymphatic sac

Dysfunction causes defective absorption of endolymph, leading to endolymphatic hydrops, which results in vertigo, tinnitus, hearing loss, and aural fullness.

Cochlear duct (scala media)

Distension of the cochlear duct affects hearing, leading to sensorineural hearing loss. It is the primary site affected in the auditory portion of the inner ear.

Saccule

Distended saccule may press against the stapes footplate, potentially contributing to vestibular symptoms and vertigo in the advanced stages of the disease. (Option C)

Semicircular canals

Secondary involvement causes vestibular symptoms such as vertigo, but they are not the primary site of the pathology in Ménière’s disease. (Option A)

Reissner membrane

In severe cases, the bulging of this membrane can result in herniation into the scala vestibuli, worsening the symptoms of vertigo and hearing loss. (Option D)

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman experiences brief vertigo when turning in bed. A test is performed as shown below, and horizontal nystagmus is observed. Which of the following tests was performed?
questions.explanation:
Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV)
  • Characterized by vertigo triggered by specific head positions, such as reaching for something overhead.
  • Most common type of peripheral vertigo

M/c Canal Affected

Posterior semicircular canal > Horizontal semicircular canal > Anterior semicircular canal

Etiology

  • Head trauma (M/c cause)
  • Vestibular neuritis
  • Otosclerosis
  • Meniere’s disease

Otoconia

Calcium carbonate crystals embedded in the macula of the utricle and saccule.

Mechanism

  • Displaced otolith from the utricle stimulates cupula of the posterior semicircular canal causing vertigo and nystagmus.
  • Changes in head position with gravity lead to abnormal displacement of the cupula in the affected semicircular canal, stimulating vestibular afferents.
  • This results in characteristic abnormal eye movements and vertigo.

Symptoms

  • Episodic vertigo lasting for seconds
  • Positional vertigo: Imbalance on lying down, sitting up from a lying position, or rolling in bed or when flexing the neck.
  • Vertigo (fatigable) may resolve temporarily but can recur after a period of rest.
  • ± Nausea, vomiting
  • No hearing loss
  • No neurologic symptoms
  • No tinnitus

Diagnostic Test

Dix-Hallpike Maneuver (Option B)

Supine Roll Test

(Option C)

Procedure

Image

Canal tested

Posterior semicircular canal (P-SCC) > Anterior semicircular canal (A-SCC)

Horizontal semicircular canal

Nystagmus

  • Towards affected side
  • Upbeating torsional geotropic nystagmus: P-SCC affected
  • Downbeating geotropic torsional nystagmus: A-SCC affected

Horizontal geotropic nystagmus towards the affected side

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman with vertigo triggered by head position changes is diagnosed with posterior semicircular canal (P-SCC) BPPV. Which of the following maneuvers is not used primarily for treating P-SCC BPPV?
questions.explanation:
Posterior Semicircular Canal BPPV

Horizontal Semicircular Canal BPPV
  1. Epley’s maneuver (best) (Option A)
  2. Semont’s liberatory maneuver (Option B)
  3. Brandt-Daroff positional exercises (Option C)
  1. Forced prolonged position on the healthy side
  2. 270° Barbecue maneuver
  3. 360° Yaw rotation
  4. Liberatory maneuver
  5. Gufoni maneuver

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with acute onset of severe vertigo, nausea, and vomiting that has been persistent for the last 24 hours. He has right horizontal nystagmus that worsens with head movement. His hearing is normal, and there are no signs of weakness or dysarthria. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Etiology

Inflammation of the vestibular nerve, commonly due to viral infection (e.g., reactivation of HSV). Other causes include vascular and immunologic origins.

Affected Structures

Vestibular portion of the CN VIII, primarily affecting the superior portion of the vestibular labyrinth.

Symptoms

Vertigo

Nausea/Vomiting

Balance issues

Management

Antiemetics (promethazine, metoclopramide)

Antihistamines (meclizine, diphenhydramine)

Benzodiazepines (diazepam, lorazepam)

Feature

Peripheral Vertigo (e.g., Vestibular Neuritis)

Central Vertigo (e.g., Cerebellar Stroke)

Onset of Symptoms

Sudden, constant vertigo

Sudden or gradual; can be constant or episodic

Nystagmus

Unidirectional, worsens with gaze in the direction of fast component

Multidirectional or vertical, may change direction with gaze

Hearing Involvement

Normal (in vestibular neuritis); Ménière’s involves hearing loss

No hearing involvement

Neurological Signs

Absent

Present (e.g., dysarthria, incoordination, limb weakness)

Duration of Vertigo

Days to weeks

Variable, may persist

Head Movement

Worsens symptoms

Often no impact

Examples

Vestibular neuritis, BPPV, Ménière’s disease

Cerebellar stroke, multiple sclerosis

questions.text: A 12-year-old child with a history of temporal bone abnormalities presents with recurrent episodes of vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and tinnitus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Feature

Description

Etiology

Can occur after head trauma, barotrauma (e.g., diving), temporal bone anomalies, or ear surgery (e.g., stapedectomy).

Symptoms

Fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss, vertigo, tinnitus, and sometimes a sense of fullness in the ear.

Complications

Recurrent meningitis (especially in children with temporal bone defects), cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leak.

Diagnosis

Often clinical, based on history and symptoms; confirmed through surgical exploration if suspected.

Temporal bone CT: Shows pneumolabyrinth, accumulation of fluid in the middle ear, and/or ossicular chain disruption, but also can often be normal.

Treatment

Surgical closure of the fistula to prevent further complications, such as meningitis; limited improvement in hearing.

Prognosis

Hearing improvement post-surgery is usually limited; however, vertigo symptoms often improve or resolve.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with intermittent vertigo, hearing his footsteps loudly and a sensation of fullness in his ear. He experiences vertigo triggered by loud noises and changes in pressure, but there is no history of recent infection or trauma. An audiogram is done, and it suggests Mixed hearing loss. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Condition

Hearing Loss Type

Vertigo Trigger

Key Features

Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD)

Mixed

Loud sounds, pressure changes

Autophony, pulsatile tinnitus, air-bone gap, Tullio phenomenon, third window effect

Labyrinthitis

Sensorineural

Spontaneous, after infection

Acute onset, post-viral/bacterial, vertigo with hearing loss, no CHL

Ménière's Disease

Sensorineural

Spontaneous, episodic

Episodic vertigo, aural fullness, tinnitus, fluctuating hearing loss

Vestibular Neuronitis

None

Sudden onset, spontaneous

Sudden vertigo, no hearing loss, likely viral etiology, resolves in days to weeks
